awd_titl_txt: Point Defects in Gallium Nitride: Experiment and Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Gallium nitride (GaN) is a key component in optoelectronics, such as light-emitting diodes (LED). The investigation and identification of point defects in GaN is very important and has immediate technology relevance to longer life time LEDs. The goal of the proposed research is to bring the physics of defects in GaN to a new level of understanding, to uncover the microscopic nature of defects, and to solve longstanding problems in the field of semiconductor physics. The research integrates experiment and theory by combining advanced experimental techniques with high performance computing. Collaboration with the semiconductor industry is expected to have a direct impact on practical applications. The project also builds a strong foundation for research and education in a relatively small Physics Department at Virginia Commonwealth University. Students from underrepresented groups have the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with state-of-the-art experiment and calculations.

Technical Description: The goal of this research is to gain an in-depth and comprehensive understanding of point defects in GaN. The study investigates a large number of point defects and various defect complexes. The experimental work, using advanced tools such as photoluminescence under uniaxial stress, is conducted in parallel with first-principles calculations using the hybrid functional theory. Incorporation of lattice deformations due to uniaxial pressure into the theory enables direct comparison between the theory-predicted changes in defect-related optical properties and experimental results. The symmetry and electronic structure of point defects can be revealed from the analysis of the effect of external stress based on the luminescence spectrum and its polarization. The integrated experiment/theory approach allows the direct identification of defects and the determination of their microscopic structure.

por.por_cntn:
Point defects (including native atomic-size defects of crystal lattice and intentionally introduced impurities) play important role in properties of semiconductors and in operation of semiconductor devices. In particular, the presence of minuscule amounts of uncontrolled and unrecognized defects can dramatically reduce efficiency and longevity of light-emitting devices such as white LEDs. Gallium nitride (GaN) semiconductor is a key component in white LEDs. However, up to now, point defects in this semiconductor are poorly understood.

In the four years of the project, the team of theorists and experimentalists at the Department of Physics at VCU conducted successful research in the area of point defects in GaN and achieved significant progress in this field. The team included two professors (a theorist and an experimentalist) and six graduate students. In experiment, photoluminescence from GaN was the major tool in detection, recognition, and identification of point defects and evaluation of their properties. We have demonstrated that photoluminescence can provide quantitative information such as the concentration of a particular type of defects (down to few parts per trillion) and the absolute quantum efficiency of a particular electron-hole recombination channel. State-of-the-art theoretical calculations predicted properties of specific species of defects that could be compared with experimentally observed properties. As a result, defects (their chemical origin and microscopic structure) could be identified. We have resolved several long-standing problems in the field of point defects in GaN. In particular, the origin of the yellow luminescence, a four-decade-long puzzle is finally understood, and the properties of the related defect (carbon impurity) are described in detail. Another puzzle – the so-called dual nature of acceptors in GaN doped with Mg – is also resolved. Several defects in high-quality GaN semiconductor are identified and their properties are tabulated.        

Overall, the project provided substantial educational and training opportunities for 6 graduate students, three of whom graduated with a Ph.D. degree in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology and three others graduated with M.S. degree in Physics. Work under this grant contributed to one book chapter and 15 refereed journal articles in prestigious journals such as Physical Review Letters, Physical Review B, Scientific Reports, and Journal of Applied Physics. The results were reported at 15 conferences (totally 22 presentations), including International Conference on Defects in Semiconductors, International Conference on Physics in Semiconductors, International Workshop on Nitride Semiconductors, AVS International Symposium, American Physical Society meetings, and others.

Two semiconductor companies (Kyma Technologies, Inc. and Nitride Crystals, Inc.) expressed significant interest in the project. Both companies provided large quantities of GaN samples for our experimental research. Leading researchers of these companies participated in discussion of results and preparation of publications. The results obtained in this project, in particular the roles and properties of defects that can be formed during crystal growth, will help the semiconductor industry to produce semiconductor material and devices with superior quality.

The project has built a strong foundation for research and education in a small Physics Department at Virginia Commonwealth University (10 faculty members and about 10 graduate students). It was a unique opportunity for students to explore simultaneously experimental and theoretical approaches and learn basic physics of defects in semiconductors. Students from underrepresented groups got the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with state-of-the-art experiment and calculations. Specifically, two women and one African American have graduated with support of this grant.
